Under the Five-Year Plan (NFYP, 2002-2007), the Government of 
Bhutan  (the  Government)  intends  to  electrify  15,000  households. 
Under the project, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) will assist 
the  Government  to  electrify  about  8,000  rural  consumers,  mostly 
households,  but  including  hospitals,  schools,  and  other  public 
facilities  for  local  communities.  The  8,000  consumers  were 
selected based on social and technical criteria to ensure that 43% 
of  the  households  connected  are  below  the  poverty  line.    Based 
on  this  criteria,  eight  districts  were  selected  for  the  Project: 
Chhukha,  Lhuentse,  Mongar,  Pemagatshel,  Punakha,  Samtse, 
Sarpang,  and  Trashigang.    The  Government  expects  to  get 
financial assistance from the Government of the Netherlands and 
the  Government  of  Austria  to  finance  the  electrification  of  4,000 
households.    The  Government  is  expected  to  make  funds 
available to finance the remaining 3,000 households.  The Project 
will (i) construct 390 circuit kilometers (cct-km) of 33 kilo-volt (kV) 
overhead lines; (ii) construct 300 cct-km of 11 kV overhead lines; 
(iii) 
install  160  33/0.4  kV  and  170  11/0.4  kV  distribution 
transformers  with  associated  drop-out  fuse  assemblies  and  low 
voltage  (LV)  boards;  (iv)  install  570  cct-km  of  LV  aerial  bundled 
conductors;  and  (v)  installation  of  service  cables  and  energy 
meters  to  8,000  customers.    The  Government  and  ADB  are  also 
engaged  in  a  long-term  policy  dialogue  to  restructure  the  power 
sector  in  order  to  improve  sector  efficiency.  As  a  result  of  this 
dialogue,  the  former  Department  of  Power  was  unbundled 
creating  the  Department  of  Energy  (DOE)  as  the  governmental 
planning agency, Bhutan Electricity Authority (BEA) as the sector 
regulator, and BPC as the a transmission, distribution and supply 
corporation.  Two  technical  assistance  (TA)  projects  are  piggy-
backed  to  the  Project  and  represent  the  next  step  in  sector 
restructuring.

indigenous  hydropower  energy,  the  distribution  of  electricity 
throughout  the  country  is  still  limited.    According  to  the  most 
recent  estimates,  the  population  of  Bhutan  is  about  695,000,  of 
whom 80% reside in rural areas. About 66,000 of the 85,000 rural 
households are without electricity. The Project will bring additional 
social and economic benefits including improved living standards 
and conditions for education and health service delivery; and

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  provided  a  project  preparatory  TA1  with  the 
2. 
objective of (i) establishing the technical, economic, financial, and social feasibility of the project; 
and  (ii)  providing  the  Department  of  Energy  (DOE)  and  the  Bhutan  Power  Corporation  (BPC) 
with capacity for preparing similar future projects for external financing.  The project framework 
is in Appendix 1. 
 
Most  of  Bhutan’s  power  comes  from  run-of-the-river  hydropower  from  the  four  major 
3. 
rivers: Ammochu, Mangdechhu, Samkosh, and Wangchu. Currently, Bhutan has 26 hydropower 
stations with a total installed capacity of about 445 megawatts (MW) and a maximum demand of 
96  MW.    There  are  currently  three  main  generating  companies:  Chhukha  Hydropower 
Corporation  (CHPC,  336  MW,  funded  by  India)  and  the  Baso  Chhu  (Phase  1)  Hydropower 
Corporation  (BHPC,  24  MW,  funded  by  Austria)  in  the  Western  Region  and  Kurichhu 
Hydropower  Corporation  (KHPC,  60MW,  funded  by  India)  in  the  Eastern  Region.  All  three 
companies are wholly Government-owned.  Although CHPC, KHPC, and BHPC provide most of 
the power capacity, there are eight mini-hydro plants with capacities ranging from 300 kilowatt 
(kW) to 2,200 kW, and 15 microhydro plants with capacities ranging from 8 kW to 200 kW. The 
total installed capacity of microhydro plants has reached about 1,000 kW.  Baso Chhu Phase 2 
will be completed in 2004 (40 MW, funded by Austria) and the Tala Hydropower Project (THPC, 
1,020 MW, funded by India) will be completed by 2006.  The theoretical potential hydropower in 
Bhutan  is  30,000  MW.    DOE  has  conducted  prefeasibility  and  feasibility  studies  on  projects 
totaling  16,280  MW.    Further,  the  Governments  of  Norway  and  Japan  have  funded  full-scale 
technical feasibility studies for the Mangdechhu Hydropower Project (completed in 1999 for 360 
MW) and Punatsangchu Hydropower Project (completed in 2001 for 870 MW). 
 
4. 
Hydropower  is  Bhutan’s  most  important  natural  resource.    Because  the  country 
generates  significantly  more  electricity  than  it  consumes,  Bhutan  is  a  net  power  exporter.    In 
FY2001,  power  exports  of  1,380  gigawatt-hours  (77  percent  of  the  energy  the  country 
generated) to India accounted for over 43% of the national revenue.  Almost all this power came 
from CHPC and as such, CHPC is the largest single foreign exchange earner of Bhutan.  Under 
the current power purchase agreement with India, CHPC and KHPC are under no obligation to 
export  any  fixed  amount  of  capacity  or  energy  to  India.    Their  first  priority  is  to  supply  the 
necessary  electricity  to  BPC  for  domestic  consumers.    Only  the  balance  of  the  country’s 
electricity  output  is  to  be  exported  to  India.    As  such,  there  is  no  excess  generation  capacity.  
Given this situation, the Government has put the highest priority on developing its hydropower

B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

1. 

Nature of Rural Electrification in Bhutan 

 
 
Given  Bhutan’s  mountainous  terrain  and  highly  dispersed  population,  the  expansion  of 
7. 
the  rural  electrification  (RE)  network  system  poses  additional  challenges.    The  RE  system 
expansion  has  outpaced  the  extension  of  the  road  network.    As  a  result,  the  cost  of  grid 
extension  and  household  connections  are  high,  currently  averaging  about  $1,400  per 
household.    Costs  will  increase  even  further  as  RE  moves  to  even  more  remote  villages  and 
households.  Given this situation, DOE, BPC, and ADB have worked hard on the technical and 
economic  balance  in  the  design  of  the  Project  to  ensure  subprojects  that  are  techno-
economically feasible.  However, for future RE extension, the subprojects will be in even more 
remote areas as the more accessible villages are usually the ones to get electrified first.  This 
will  affect  the  technical  as  well  as  economic  viability  of  future  grid  extension.    Future  projects 
may have to weigh the benefits and the costs of grid extension against off-grid applications such 
as micro and minihydro stations with a small grid, community solar photo-voltaic (PV) charging 
stations, or household PV systems. 
 

2.

A. 

Objectives 

The  proposed  loan  will  fund  a  poverty  intervention  project  with  economic  growth  as  its 
19.

national hydropower stations as an important and necessary input to rural residents in Bhutan to 
improve  their  living  standards,  conditions  for  education,  and  health  service  delivery;  and  (ii) 
provide  the  rural  poor  with  opportunities  to  increase  their  economic  productivity,  create  and

B. 

Components and Outputs 

20. 
Under the NFYP, the Government intends to electrify 15,000 households.  ADB provided 
a  PPTA  to  DOE  and  BPC  to  undertake  the  technical  design,  and  financial,  economic,  social, 
and  environmental  analyses  for  electrifying  the  15,000  households  and  other  consumers.    Of 
the 15,000 households, the Project will electrify about 8,000 rural consumers and a population 
of about 50,000.  The Project will also electrify hospitals, schools, and other public facilities for 
local  communities.    This  will  correspond  to  an  increase  of  about  20%  in  the  total  number  of 
consumers served by BPC, or an 8% increase in the total proportion of the national population 
with electricity supply, from the current 35% to about 43%. The 8,000 consumers were selected 
based on social and technical criteria to ensure that 43% of the households connected are living 
below the poverty line (para. 21).  The project will (i) construct 390 circuit kilometers (cct-km) of 
33 kilo-volt (kV) overhead lines; (ii) construct 300 cct-km of 11 kV overhead lines; (iii) install 160 
33/0.4 kV and 170 11/0.4 kV distribution transformers with associated drop-out fuse assemblies 
and  low  voltage  (LV)  boards;  (iv)  install  570  cct-km  of  LV  aerial  bundled  conductors;  and  (v) 
installation of service cables and energy meters to 8,000 customers.

21.

sufficiently  targeted  during  project  design.    Therefore,  to  meet  the  targeted  number  of

environmental considerations.  Further, the Project deemed it more effective to focus on specific

Economic Aspects 

C. 
 
48. 
The primary use of electricity by rural residential consumers is for household use. A few 
households  have  small  stores,  and  some  electricity  is  used  to  operate  equipment  in  small 
workshops.  The  economic  benefits  of  electricity  consumption  for  these  consumers  are 
evaluated  on  the  basis  of  (i)  the  alternative  economic  costs  of  other  energy  sources  such  as 
kerosene lighting or wood fuel for cooking that will be displaced by using electricity; and (ii) the 
value of additional or induced energy consumption at the estimated average willingness to pay 
for electricity based on a weighted average of the alternative costs of providing  similar energy-
related  services  and  the  current  electricity  tariff.  For  this  Project,  the  average  displaced 
kerosene consumption is about 6.2 liters per house per month, which is equivalent to 2.4 kWh of 
electricity (in terms of lumens).  Average electricity consumption in rural Bhutan is relatively high 
at 90.5 kWh per month, due to the low average tariff of only Nu0.71/kWh, thus most electricity 
used  is  induced  additional  energy.  The  weighted  average  economic  value  of  residential 
electricity  consumption  is  estimated  to  be  Nu9.1/kWh  in  this  model12  (or  $0.19/kWh).  This 
includes  an  average  increase  in  household  income  estimated  to  be  about  Nu78  per  month,  or 
about 1% of overall average household income13. It also includes improved health standards due 
to a cleaner environment without kerosene lamps, with less cooking over smoky cooking fires in 
case of houses with electric cooking appliances, and better preservation of food for houses with 
refrigerators.  Health  benefits  are  estimated  to  be  an  average  of  about  Nu37  per  month  per 
household,  based  on  lower  costs  of  medical  care  required,  and  reduced  number  of  sick  days. 
Appendix 3 provides a more detailed description of the economic evaluation of these benefits. 
 
49. 
By  2007,  when  the  Project  is  fully  completed,  it  will  serve  an  estimated  8,000  rural 
households with a population of about 50,000. This number corresponds to an increase of about 
20% in the total number of consumers served by BPC. It represents an 8% increase in the total 
proportion of the national population with electricity supply, from the current 35% to about 43%. 
The estimated capital cost of the Project is $12.1 million total for distribution at 33 kV and lower, 
including  consumer  connection  costs  and  physical  contingencies.  This  corresponds  to  an 
average  cost  of  $1,425  per  household  served.  The  economic  evaluation  of  the  RE  project  is 
based on the average unit benefits and capital costs described above,14 average sales of 90.5 
kWh per month per household, an average cost for bulk power supply of Nu1.38 /kWh based on 
the  current  tariff  and  opportunity  cost  for  bulk  power  exports  to  India,  less  the  cost  of 
transmission wheeling for power exports, plus allowances for domestic transmission costs and 
transmission and distribution losses. Based on these assumptions, the economic internal rate of 
return  is  conservatively  estimated  at  12.7%  for  the  base  case.  Data  regarding  other  benefits 
such as increased useful hours for leisure or housekeeping in the evenings, improved access to 
modern communications and entertainment facilities such as radio and TV, and a better overall 
quality of life with electricity, is not readily available. Thus, these benefits have not been included.

Environmental Aspects 

 
D. 
 
51. 
The  project  is  categorized  as  a  “B”  Project  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  environmental 
impact assessment (EIA). The Project, which includes only distribution lines and pole-mounted 
transformers,  is  also  subject  to  Bhutan’s  Environmental  Assessment  Act  2000.    An  Initial 
Environmental  Examination  (IEE)  was  prepared  (Appendix  14) 
to  provide  adequate 
environmental assessment.  Based on the IEE, the following issues were raised and addressed. 
(i) The environmental impacts associated with the Project will not be significant (because it will 
not change the land use below the distribution lines and the line alignments will, to the extent 
possible, be located along or close to existing roads or tracks).  However, some stretches of the 
distribution line will pass through forestlands.  Distribution lines that pass through medium and 
dense  forestlands  will  be  minimized.    For  the  most  part,  distribution  lines  will  pass  through 
forestlands with sparse vegetation coverage so that environmental impacts from tree cutting will 
not  be  significant.    In  any  case,  construction  work  will  be  undertaken  only  after  approval  for 
forest clearance is obtained from Department of Forestry Services (DOF) and land clearing will 
be limited only to the area granted the clearance. (ii) A stretch of distribution line in Punakha will 
enter  the  buffer  zone  and  multiple-use  zone  of  Jigme  Dorji  National  Park.  However,  it  will  not 
create a significant impact because only about 5 km of the line will enter these zones, and these 
areas are mostly agricultural lands and have no  ecological significance. Construction works in 
these  areas  will  be  undertaken  only  after  DOF  approval  is  obtained.    Further,  during 
construction,  there  will  be  ongoing  consultation  with  the  park  management  officers.  (iii)  The 
environmental impacts associated with the construction period will be minor.  In most cases the 
construction  materials  and  equipment  will  be  manually  transported  from  the  nearest  road. 
Because  land  clearing  in  locations  with  steep  slope  gradients  may  trigger  erosion  problems, 
planting grass to provide ground cover will be done simultaneously during the construction work 
or immediately after construction is completed. Adequate ground cover will avoid pole damage 
due to landslides. All poles will be located with adequate distance from water bodies. (iv) The 
operations  stage  will  not  create  any  environmental  impact.  However,  routine  line  maintenance 
involving trimming of bushes or other vegetation under the lines, particularly in the forest areas, 
will be done in such a way that it will not to affect the forest ecosystem.  Routine maintenance 
for  the  pole-mounted  transformers  will  generate  only  a  small  amount  of  waste  oil  (about  0.5 
liters per year based on previous experience), which is reused for lubrication. Further, the waste 
oil  will  not  contain  polychlorinated  biphenyls  (PCBs)  as  BPC  only  uses  PCB-free  transformers 
for  new  construction.  (v)  BPC  will  ensure  that  all  construction  works  under  the  Project  will  be 
undertaken only after the environmental clearance from the National Environment Commission 
(NEC) is obtained 
 
52. 
Overall environmental impacts are deemed to be minor. The Project will not involve the 
accelerated use of scarce resources; neither will it favor the use of scarce resources to satisfy 
short-term over long-term socioeconomic needs. The project will contribute to more efficient use 
of  resources  by  improving  the  efficiency  of  energy  use  by  rural  households  and  reducing  the 
consumption  of  fuelwood  and  air-polluting  kerosene.  The  IEE  also  found  that  the  project  will 
have negligible effects on the ecology of the Project area and will have a significantly positive 
overall  effect  on  the  socioeconomic  well-being  of  the  rural  population  that  are  beneficiaries  of 
the  Project.    An  environmental  management  and  monitoring  plan  has  been  prepared.    During 
construction,  regular  inspections  will  be  conducted,  particularly  during  the  rainy  season,  to 
ensure that contractors are complying with all clauses in the contract documentation specifying 
mitigation measures and mechanisms for environmental protection (revegetation and provision 
of adequate ground cover). On these basis, an EIA is not necessary.

2. 
Most of Bhutan’s power comes from run-of-the-river hydropower from four major rivers. 
Currently,  Bhutan  has  26  run-of-the-river  hydropower  stations  with  a  total  installed  capacity  of 
about 445 megawatts (MW) with a maximum demand of 96 MW.  There are currently three main 
generating  companies:    Chhukha  Hydropower  Corporation  (CHPC  336  MW,  funded  by  India), 
Kurichhu Hydropower Corporation (KHPC 60 MW, funded by India) in the eastern region, and 
the  Baso  Chhu  (Phase  1)  Hydropower  Corporation  (BHPC  24  MW,  funded  by  Austria)  in  the 
western  region.  All  three  companies  are  wholly  Government-owned.    Although  the  CHPC, 
KHPC,  BHPC  provide  most  of  the  power  capacity,  there  are  eight  minihydro  plants  with 
capacities  ranging  from  300  kilowatts  (kW)  to  2,200  kW,  and  15  microhydro  plants  with 
capacities ranging from 8 kW to 200 kW. The total installed capacity of micro-hydropower plants 
has reached about 1,000 kW.  The Baso Chhu Phase 2 is expected to be completed in 2004 (40 
MW,  funded  by  Austria),  and  the  Tala  Hydropower  Project  (1,020  MW,  funded  by  India)  is 
expected  to  be  completed  by  2005.    The  theoretical  potential  for  hydropower  in  Bhutan  is 
30,000  MW.    The  Department  of  Energy  (DOE)  has  conducted  prefeasibility  and  feasibility 
studies on projects totaling 16,280 MW.  The Governments of Norway and Japan have funded 
full-scale  technical  feasibility  studies  for  the  Mangdechhu  Hydropower  Project  (completed  in 
1999  for  360  MW)  and  Punatsangchhu  Hydropower  Project  (completed  in  2001  for  870  MW).

as the corporate body under which each hydropower station will be managed as an operating

Economic Benefits of Electricity Consumption 

 
A. 
 
 
 
1. 
Electricity  sold  for  rural  electrification  is  used  primarily  by  residential  consumers  for 
household use.  A few households with small stores, use some electricity to operate equipment in 
small  workshops.  The  economic  benefits  of  electricity  consumption  for  these  consumers  are 
evaluated by valuing: (i) the alternative economic costs of other energy sources such as kerosene 
for  lighting  or  wood  fuel  for  cooking,  that  will  be  displaced  by  using  electricity;  and  (ii)  the 
additional  or  induced  energy  consumption  at  the  estimated  average  willingness  to  pay  for 
electricity,  based  on  a  weighted  average  of  the  alternative  costs  of  providing  similar  energy-
related services and the current electricity tariff. 
 
For this Project, the displaced kerosene consumption is about 6.2 liters/house/month on 
2. 
average,  which  is  equivalent  to  2.4  kilowatt-hours  (kWh)  of  electricity.  Average  electricity 
consumption in rural Bhutan is relatively high at 90.5 kWh/month, due to the low average tariff of 
only Nu0.7 kWh; thus most electricity used is induced additional energy. The weighted average 
economic  value  of  residential  electricity  consumption  is  estimated  to  be  Nu9.0/kWh  in  this 
model1.  A  further  refinement  was  made  to  consider  alternative  cooking  costs.  In  accordance 
with  the  findings  of  the  Technical  Assistance  (TA’s  Phase  1  Socioeconomic  Impact  of  Rural 
Electrification  Report2  (the  Phase  1  survey),  about  12%  of  total  electricity  consumption  in  rural 
areas  in  Bhutan  is  used  for  cooking3,  and  the  average  value  of  such  use  is  estimated  to  be 
about Nu5.0/kWh, based on alternative costs of firewood and an allowance for the convenience 
of electric cooking. This reduced the weighted  average  value of electricity use for  lighting and 
cooking only slightly. 
 
3.

average  cost  of  about  $0.31/kWh.  Details  of  this  calculation  are  shown  in  Supplementary

extension of the distribution grid.  Grid extensions in Bhutan would be more costly than diesel 
when the average cost of a grid extension exceeds $2,750 per household (the switching value). 
However,  at  this  cost  level  neither  option  would  be  considered  economically  viable  since  for 
both the average costs would exceed the average economic benefits of supply to consumers.  
(ii)  A  few  demonstration  projects  for  household  solar  photovoltaic  (PV)  systems  in  rural  areas 
have also been developed in Bhutan (1,300 units in total).  While these PV systems were given 
free,  their  maintenance  and  sustainability  continue  to  be  problematic  to  date.  Average  capital 
costs  are  about  $800  for  a  basic  low-capacity  household  system  (3  compact  florescent  lamps 
lights of 15 watts each), and the average economic cost of electricity used are about $1.80/kWh.  
While this may be considered for minimum lighting requirements in remote rural areas, it is too 
costly for larger scale applications. (iii) A few off-grid minihydro projects of less than 1000 kW 
have  also  been  developed  in  Bhutan,  and  have  been  studied  and  proposed  for  external 
financing on a grant basis.  However, they are relatively costly, with an average cost of about 
$5,000 per household served for power plant capacity and associated distribution. This is much 
more  costly  than  extension  of  the  integrated  distribution  grid  as  planned  under  the  Project.  
Furthermore, good off-grid minihydro projects are only available in a few locations.

1. 
The  director  of  the  Department  of  Energy  (DOE)  will  have  overall  responsibility  for  the

requirements.  BEA  is  currently  a  nascent  body  whose  staff  has  little  experience  in  drafting,

the BEA staff and other counterparts to assess the technical and institutional needs, as well as

medium-term  training  program.  Based  on  the  capacity  building  needs  assessment,  the

staff,  under  the  guidance  of  the  consultants,  will  design  an  outreach  strategy  to  introduce 
themselves to their stakeholders, mainly electricity consumers, explain their role, and show how 
they may serve them. (v) Explore the possibility of establishing a combined national regulatory 
body that would regulate public utilities. Given the small size of the market for various utilities in 
Bhutan,  there  may  be  efficiencies  and  economies  of  scale  in  combining  the  various  utility 
regulators,  e.g.,  power,  telecommunications,  cable  television,  and  other  future  regulators  such

Project  will  examine  the  pros  and  cons  of  a  public  utilities  regulatory  body  and  propose  a 
structure for such a body, including the methodology for the transitioning from several regulators
